title: 'Big stick' hurts telcos as well as energy, banks
text:
But he is concerned that increased government regulation of business and oversight of boards of directors might have unintended consequences.

"What I do worry about is that if we go too far you start to weaken organisations because they spend their entire time dealing with governments and all these other matters to the detriment of the actual performance of the company, particularly in some of the industries on the nose a little bit today like banking and energy.

"These are absolutely fundamentally critical industries to Australia, and we need them to be robust and strong industries. But that doesn't mean they should be cavalier and allowed to do whatever they want in the world – of course not.

"But that's what we've always got to balance with this desire to regulate with what makes the company dynamic, quick to move and healthy."

Doubled down

He is also concerned about the anti-business sentiment in Australia.

"Big business is owned basically by mum and dad shareholders these days through this fund or that fund," he said.

"Business is not some alien life form out there that should be stopped and banned – it's us, it's ordinary Australians."

Advertisement

In the interview, Mr Mullen doubled down on last week’s call for an urgent co-operative effort by business and government to fix the economics of the wholesale broadband network, NBN Co.

“The sooner we can all sit down and just put an Australian hat on rather than individual areas of interest and see how we address this the better,” he said.

Mr Mullen told Telstra’s annual meeting the NBN was not affordable for consumers and the thin profit margins it allowed for retail service providers would ultimately strangle telco capital investment.

His speech caused a storm when he said Telstra must bear some of the blame for the state of the NBN “due to its recalcitrance in helping government at the time”.

National importance

Those to have weighed in on the NBN debate include former Telstra chairman Don McGauchie, former competition regulator Graeme Samuel, former Howard government finance minister Nick Minchin and NBN Co chief executive Stephen Rue.

Communications minister Paul Fletcher has already dismissed Mr Mullen’s comments in an op-ed in the Financial Review.

He said: “The most important public policy question is whether broadband consumers are better off – and the answer unambiguously is yes.”

Advertisement

But Mr Mullen believes the issue is of such national importance he has repeated his call for co-operative action.

“We've got a very good relationship with the minister’s office and obviously the last thing I want to be seen to do is make life difficult for them and knocking where we are,” he said.

“I think we all in the industry realise this is an issue and at some stage we've got to fix it. It's in everyone's interest: the government, NBN, all the resellers and, ultimately, the consumer.

“It really is genuinely – it's not just words – it is genuinely in everyone's interests.”

Diverting resources

Mr Mullen said he was shocked at the response to his comments about Telstra’s hand in creating the current NBN business model.

“My comments at the AGM we're supposed to be 5 per cent of how we got here and 95 per cent on what we should collectively be doing about it,” he said.

“But the reaction was 95 per cent who did what to who and 5 per cent what we're doing about it, which is a shame.

Advertisement

“We've never complained about the NBN servicing the enterprise market. They're entitled to do that and, in fact, we're actively partnering with them in a number of services to customers.

“But what we do object to is that the NBN is designed to be a wholesale provider and would not favour or discriminate between the RSPs and clearly that does appear to be happening from what the ACCC said and our own information.

“The other concern, I guess, is it does seem odd that they would be diverting resources to overbuild the existing infrastructure when the consumer rollout isn’t complete and the large number of people are yet to be connected.”

'Eventually gravity prevails'

Asked what he thought about the NBN ultimately moving into private ownership Mr Mullen used this as an opportunity to talk about the broken economics of the NBN model.

“We've studiously avoided getting involved in the sort of policy levers of the nation – I think that's for government,” he said.

“The government has said – both sides of politics have said – their ultimate goal is to return the NBN to private ownership.

“We are working on the assumption that either side of politics will deliver that one day.

Advertisement

“All we have really done is just try to focus on the affordability of broadband, which is why we have called for a reduction, along with the rest of the industry, in wholesale prices.

“How we get there is really not for Telstra to decide. We’ll let the government do that.

“But we really think that it is fundamentally important that we do achieve that affordability. Eventually gravity prevails in economics, like anywhere else.

“We went from a handful of RSPs effectively to, I think, over 180 at maximum, all reselling the NBN.

“The basic economics are that for the average RSP it still costs about 55 bucks a month per use, and we're charging less than $70 as an industry.

“So, eventually one of two things will happen – either people will withdraw from reselling the NBN because it's just not economic to do it, or the retail consumer will have to go up to a point where we make enough of a margin to be able to have a viable business.

“And I can't see either of those are really in the nation's interests.”

Advertisement

He repeated comments made at the Telstra AGM by chief executive Andy Penn that "most telcos’ return on invested capital is already below their cost of capital."

Mr Mullen said: “Our mobile networks are the envy of the world. We're always consistently in the top five in the world. We're investing. We invested $4 billion last year alone. And I think the industry in Australia overall is about $12 billion a year or something like that.

“It's absolutely critical if we're going to maintain the standards that we have that we generate enough cash to do that.”

Mr Mullen refused to comment on the current stance of the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission in mobile networks. The ACCC has banned the merger of Vodafone and TPG Telecom, a move challenged in the federal court.
description: Telstra chairman John Mullen has added telecommunication to banking and energy as key sectors where 'big stick' regulatory and political risks are undermining investment returns and the economic growth outlook.
